captions.text:
- [Voiceover] Finding a great
bra can often feel impossible,
but if you follow a few easy tips,

your girls will rest
easy in the perfect home.
Let's figure out your perfect bra size.
First, find your band size in inches

by bringing measuring
tape around your back
and directly under your breasts.
Measure from around your back again,

but this time, bring
the measuring tape over
the fullest part of your breast.

Then take the difference
between this number
and your band measurement.

Each inch difference between
your band and cup measurements
brings you up a cup size.

Remember that the cup sizes
reduce with lower band sizes.
So the cup of a 38B is bigger than a 36B.
It's always a good idea to try a bra on.
Every bra will feel and look different,
so use your measurement as a guide,

and adjust accordingly to
the bra style you're buying.
The best way to put on a bra

is to first put the straps
over your shoulders,
then place your breasts into the cups
and hook the back of the bra.
If you have bigger breasts, you can try
the Stoop, Scoop, and Smooth method,

where you bend over, scoop
your breasts into place
with your nipple at the center of the cup,
and then run your finger along the inside
of the top of the bra to smooth anything
that may be spilling over.
There shouldn't be gapping or crushing
when you're wearing a bra.

You should be able to get two
fingers under the back closure
of your bra.

And your breast should be
flush with your bra cups.

The band of the bra is
actually where you're getting
most of your support.
But over time, the elastic stretches out.

You should start off wearing
your bra on the last hook,

so you can compensate for
the stretching by using
tighter hooks in the future.

Your bra band should be
level with your underwire.
No higher.
You probably have a favorite bra
that you want to wear every day,

but the elastic in the
band rapidly wears out

when it isn't given time to
retract and regain strength.
Make sure that you're rotating your bras
to prevent this from happening.

It's best to hand wash
your bras in cold water
and hang them up to air dry.

Bras that are properly
cared for normally last

about eight months, depending
on factors like quality
and how often it's worn.
If you have bruises from your underwire,

or you're starting to see
more padding than actual bra,

it's probably time to
invest in something new.

So now you know how to
find, wear, and take care
of your bra.
Remember these tips, and your boobs
will never complain again.

title: Are You Wearing The Right Bra?

comments.text:
This is wrong
I am a male
Let me tell you the correct way to measure yourself for a bra
Measure under the bust, lets say you measure 32ins now the fullest say 36ins
You need to try a 34D cup bra
Reason being you need to add 2ins when the under bust measurement is even
If the measurement was odd ie 33 then you add 3ins which would put you in a 
36C
Now I can see why woman are wearing the wrong size bra most of the time 
they are not getting fitted right.
If you need any help with finding the correct size bra or what bra will be 
best for you to wear just ask.
All body shapes are different and bras need to suit your body shape.
I could go on and on but here is another tip
The band of the bra should do most of the work say 80% so if the straps are 
cutting into your shoulders you are wearing the wrong bra.
I understand how hard it is to find a good fitting bra so if you need help 
as I said just ask.
Just to make things clear I am married and not looking or anything.﻿

comments.text:
PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENT: DO NOT ADD 4 INCHES TO THE BAND MEASUREMENT! 
This will give you too loose a band and too small a cup. For years I never 
could figure out why I couldn't even fill out the 34AA cup recommended by 
the +4 sizing. The bra would fly up when I raised my arms, and the 
underwire was painful on my breast tissue. It made me feel so crappy that I 
was too lacking in womanhood for even the smallest cup size. I eventually 
learned, and feel and look much better in a 32C! Thanks to Buzzfeed for 
getting it right!﻿
